title: Data & Patterns
description: Reading the world through data and patterns. Students read and create bar graphs, line plots, and pictographs, answer questions by interpreting data displays, identify and extend number patterns with input/output tables, and get their first taste of algebraic thinking by finding missing numbers in equations using the balance concept.
goals: Read and create bar graphs, line plots, and pictographs with accurate titles, labels, and scales
Answer comparison, combination, and 'how many more/fewer' questions by interpreting data displays and citing evidence from the graph
Identify the rule in a number pattern, complete input/output tables, and describe growing patterns in words
Find missing numbers in equations using the balance concept and begin using letters to represent unknowns
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro -> I Do -> We Do -> You Do for each skill, with kid-friendly contexts like class surveys, favorite foods, and recess games
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; flexes within each phase based on student responses and comfort level
Emphasize visual literacy: every graph problem should prompt students to read the title, labels, and scale before answering any questions
For patterns and unknowns, encourage students to describe rules in their own words before writing number sentences â€” building verbal reasoning alongside symbolic thinking

scaffold.title: Reading and Creating Graphs
scaffold.content: Graphs are pictures that help us understand data. Instead of staring at a long list of numbers, we can draw a graph and see the information at a glance. In this lesson you will learn about three types of graphs: bar graphs (bars go up to show amounts), pictographs (little pictures stand for numbers), and line plots (Xs or dots above a number line). Every good graph needs three things: a title that tells what the graph is about, labels that tell what each axis or category means, and a scale or key that tells how to read the numbers.
keyPoints: A bar graph uses bars of different heights to compare categories. The taller the bar, the greater the amount.
A pictograph uses small pictures or symbols to represent data. A key tells how much each symbol is worth (e.g., one star = 2 votes).
A line plot uses Xs or dots above a number line to show how often each value occurs â€” great for measurement data.
Every graph must have a title (what the data is about), labels (what the axes or categories represent), and a scale or key (how to read the numbers or symbols).
Before answering any question about a graph, always read the title, labels, and scale first.

scaffold.title: Reading and Creating Graphs â€” Worked Examples

examples.problem:
Ms. Taylor's class voted on their favorite fruit. Here are the results:
Apples: 8 votes | Bananas: 5 votes | Grapes: 10 votes | Oranges: 3 votes
If you drew a bar graph, which bar would be the tallest? Which would be the shortest?
examples.solution: The tallest bar would be Grapes because grapes got the most votes (10). The shortest bar would be Oranges because oranges got the fewest votes (3). On the bar graph, you would label the bottom axis 'Fruit' and the side axis 'Number of Votes,' with a title like 'Our Favorite Fruits.'

examples.problem:
Students measured the lengths of 12 caterpillars to the nearest centimeter:
3, 4, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 6, 6, 7, 8
Describe how you would create a line plot for this data.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Draw a number line from 3 to 8 (the smallest to largest value).
Step 2: Put an X above each number for every caterpillar with that length.
3 cm: X (1 caterpillar)
4 cm: X X (2 caterpillars)
5 cm: X X X (3 caterpillars)
6 cm: X X X X (4 caterpillars)
7 cm: X (1 caterpillar)
8 cm: X (1 caterpillar)
Step 3: Add a title: 'Lengths of Caterpillars (cm)' and label the number line 'Length in cm.'

scaffold.title: Reading and Creating Graphs â€” Practice

problems.question:
Mr. Chen's class collected data on their favorite sport:
Soccer: 9 students | Basketball: 7 students | Baseball: 4 students | Swimming: 6 students
If you drew a bar graph, list the sports in order from tallest bar to shortest bar.
hints: The tallest bar belongs to the sport with the most students. Which sport has the highest number?
Put the numbers in order from greatest to least: 9, 7, 6, 4. Match each number to its sport.
problems.answer: From tallest bar to shortest bar: Soccer (9), Basketball (7), Swimming (6), Baseball (4). The bar graph would have 'Sport' on the bottom axis, 'Number of Students' on the side axis, and a title like 'Favorite Sports in Mr. Chen's Class.'

Students measured the length of their shoes to the nearest inch and got these results:
8, 8, 9, 9, 9, 10, 10, 10, 10, 11
How many Xs would go above the number 10 on a line plot? Which length would have the most Xs?
hints: Count how many times the number 10 appears in the data.
Count the frequency of each value: 8 appears ___ times, 9 appears ___ times, 10 appears ___ times, 11 appears ___ time.
problems.answer: The number 10 appears 4 times, so 4 Xs would go above it. Frequencies: 8 appears 2 times, 9 appears 3 times, 10 appears 4 times, 11 appears 1 time. The length 10 inches has the most Xs.

scaffold.title: Reading and Creating Graphs â€” On Your Own

problems.question:
A bar graph titled 'Snacks Sold at the School Fair' shows:
Popcorn bar reaches up to 25 | Cotton Candy bar reaches up to 18 | Pretzels bar reaches up to 12 | Fruit Cups bar reaches up to 20
List three things every good bar graph needs. Then name the snack that sold the most and the snack that sold the least.
problems.answer: Every good bar graph needs: (1) a title, (2) labels on each axis, and (3) a scale with evenly spaced numbers. The most-sold snack is Popcorn (25). The least-sold snack is Pretzels (12).

problems.question: Create a pictograph key for this situation: A library tracks books checked out each day. On Monday 15 books were checked out, Tuesday 20, and Wednesday 10. If each picture stands for 5 books, how many pictures go in each row?
problems.answer: Key: Each picture = 5 books. Monday: 15 / 5 = 3 pictures. Tuesday: 20 / 5 = 4 pictures. Wednesday: 10 / 5 = 2 pictures.

problems.question:
Ten students measured the number of raisins in their snack boxes:
12, 14, 14, 15, 15, 15, 16, 16, 17, 19
Draw a line plot in your notebook. Then answer: How many Xs are above 15? What is the range of the data (greatest value minus smallest value)?
problems.answer: There are 3 Xs above 15 (the number 15 appears 3 times). The range is 19 - 12 = 7 raisins.

scaffold.title: Interpreting Data Displays
scaffold.content: Making a graph is only the first step. The real power of a graph is answering questions. You can look at a graph and figure out how many, which is the most or least, how many more or fewer, and what the total is. The key is to use evidence from the graph â€” point to specific bars, pictures, or Xs to support your answer, just like using evidence from a reading passage.
keyPoints: 'How many' questions: read the height of a bar, count the pictures (times the key), or count the Xs above a number.
'Most' and 'least' questions: find the tallest or shortest bar, the row with the most or fewest pictures, or the number with the most or fewest Xs.
'How many more/fewer' questions: subtract the smaller amount from the larger amount.
'Combine' or 'total' questions: add the amounts for two or more categories together.
Always use evidence from the graph in your answer â€” name the categories and their values.

scaffold.title: Interpreting Data Displays â€” Worked Examples

examples.problem:
A bar graph titled 'Favorite Ice Cream Flavors' shows:
Chocolate: 12 | Vanilla: 8 | Strawberry: 6 | Mint: 4
(a) Which flavor is the most popular?
(b) How many more students chose Chocolate than Mint?
(c) How many students voted in all?
examples.solution:
(a) Chocolate is the most popular because its bar is the tallest at 12 votes.
(b) Chocolate (12) minus Mint (4) = 8 more students chose Chocolate than Mint.
(c) Total = 12 + 8 + 6 + 4 = 30 students voted in all.
Notice how each answer uses specific numbers from the graph as evidence.

examples.problem:
A line plot shows the number of jumping jacks students completed in 30 seconds:
Values on the number line: 10(XX), 11(X), 12(XXX), 13(XXXX), 14(XX), 15(X)
What number of jumping jacks was most common? How many students did fewer than 13 jumping jacks?

problems.question:
A bar graph titled 'Points Scored in Saturday's Games' shows:
Lions: 24 points | Bears: 18 points | Hawks: 30 points | Sharks: 15 points
(a) Which team scored the most points?
(b) How many more points did the Hawks score than the Bears?
(c) How many total points were scored by all four teams?
hints: For (a), find the tallest bar.
For (b), subtract: Hawks points minus Bears points.
For (c), add all four values together.
problems.answer: (a) The Hawks scored the most points (30). (b) Hawks (30) - Bears (18) = 12 more points. (c) Total = 24 + 18 + 30 + 15 = 87 points scored by all four teams.

scaffold.title: Patterns and Rules
scaffold.content: Patterns are everywhere â€” in nature, in music, and especially in math. A pattern is a sequence that follows a rule. Once you find the rule, you can predict what comes next, fill in missing pieces, and extend the pattern as far as you want. An input/output table is a special tool that shows how a rule changes one number into another. Your job is to be a pattern detective: study the numbers, find the rule, and describe it in your own words.
keyPoints: A pattern rule tells you what operation to do each time to get the next number (e.g., 'add 6' or 'multiply by 2').
Growing patterns increase each time (like 2, 5, 8, 11 â€” the rule is 'add 3'). Some patterns decrease (like 100, 90, 80 â€” the rule is 'subtract 10').
An input/output table has two columns. The rule connects each input to its output (e.g., input x 3 = output).
To find the rule in an input/output table, ask: 'What do I do to the input number to get the output number?' Try adding, subtracting, multiplying, or dividing.
Describe patterns in words: 'Start at 4 and add 5 each time' or 'Multiply the input by 3, then add 1.'

scaffold.title: Patterns and Rules â€” Worked Examples

examples.problem:
Find the rule and the next two numbers in this pattern:
5, 10, 15, 20, 25, ___, ___
examples.solution:
Look at how the numbers change:
10 - 5 = 5, 15 - 10 = 5, 20 - 15 = 5, 25 - 20 = 5.
The rule is 'add 5 each time.'
Next two numbers: 25 + 5 = 30, 30 + 5 = 35.
The pattern continues: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35.

examples.problem:
Complete this input/output table and find the rule:
| Input | Output |
|   2   |    8   |
|   5   |   20   |
|   3   |   12   |
|   7   |   ?    |
|  10   |   ?    |
examples.solution:
Check the relationship between each input and output:
2 -> 8: What do I do to 2 to get 8? 2 x 4 = 8. Could be 'multiply by 4.'
5 -> 20: 5 x 4 = 20. Yes!
3 -> 12: 3 x 4 = 12. Confirmed!
The rule is 'multiply the input by 4.'
7 -> 7 x 4 = 28.
10 -> 10 x 4 = 40.

examples.problem:
Describe this growing pattern in words and find the next two terms:
3, 7, 11, 15, 19, ___, ___

problems.question:
Find the rule and fill in the missing numbers:
8, 15, 22, 29, ___, ___, 50
hints: Find the difference between consecutive numbers: 15 - 8 = ?
Check: 22 - 15 = ? and 29 - 22 = ? If the difference is the same each time, that is your rule.
problems.answer: The difference each time is 7 (15-8=7, 22-15=7, 29-22=7). The rule is 'add 7.' Missing numbers: 29 + 7 = 36, 36 + 7 = 43. Pattern: 8, 15, 22, 29, 36, 43, 50.

problems.question:
Find the rule for this input/output table:
| Input | Output |
|   1   |    5   |
|   2   |    8   |
|   3   |   11   |
|   4   |   14   |
|   6   |   ?    |
hints: Try multiplying the input by different numbers. Does input x 5 work for all rows?
If multiplication alone does not work, try a two-step rule like 'multiply by ___ then add ___.' Check: 1 x 3 = 3, then 3 + 2 = 5. Does that work for input 2?
problems.answer: The rule is 'multiply by 3, then add 2.' Check: 1x3+2=5, 2x3+2=8, 3x3+2=11, 4x3+2=14. All match! For input 6: 6x3+2 = 20.

problems.question:
A decreasing pattern starts at 60:
60, 52, 44, 36, ___, ___
What is the rule? Describe it in words and write the next two terms.
hints: Find the difference: 60 - 52 = ?
Is the pattern going up or going down? If the numbers are getting smaller, the rule involves subtracting.
problems.answer: 60 - 52 = 8, 52 - 44 = 8, 44 - 36 = 8. The rule is 'subtract 8 each time' or 'start at 60 and take away 8 each time.' Next two terms: 36 - 8 = 28, 28 - 8 = 20. Pattern: 60, 52, 44, 36, 28, 20.

scaffold.title: Patterns and Rules â€” On Your Own

problems.question:
A coach records how many laps the team runs each week:
Week 1: 4 laps | Week 2: 7 laps | Week 3: 10 laps | Week 4: 13 laps
What is the rule? How many laps will they run in Week 6?
problems.answer: The rule is 'add 3 each week.' Week 5: 13 + 3 = 16 laps. Week 6: 16 + 3 = 19 laps.

problems.question:
Complete the input/output table and state the rule:
| Input | Output |
|   3   |    9   |
|   5   |   15   |
|   8   |   24   |
|   4   |   ?    |
|  12   |   ?    |
problems.answer: The rule is 'multiply by 3.' Check: 3x3=9, 5x3=15, 8x3=24. For input 4: 4x3=12. For input 12: 12x3=36.

problems.question:
Look at this pattern:
2, 6, 18, 54, ___
This is NOT an adding pattern. What operation is being used? Describe the rule in words and find the next term.
problems.answer: Each number is multiplied by 3 to get the next number: 2x3=6, 6x3=18, 18x3=54. The rule is 'multiply by 3 each time.' The next term is 54 x 3 = 162.

scaffold.title: Finding Missing Numbers â€” The Balance Concept
scaffold.content: The equals sign does not mean 'here comes the answer.' It means both sides are balanced â€” like a seesaw with equal weight on each side. When you see 3 + 5 = 8, it means the left side (3 + 5) has the same value as the right side (8). When a number is missing, like square + 5 = 12, your job is to find the number that keeps both sides balanced. You can use a box (square), a question mark, or even a letter like n. Finding the missing number is the very beginning of algebra!
keyPoints: The equals sign means 'the same as' â€” both sides must have the same value.
A missing number can be shown with a box (square), a blank, a question mark, or a letter like n or x.
To find a missing addend, use subtraction: if square + 5 = 12, then square = 12 - 5 = 7.
To find a missing number being subtracted, think addition: if 15 - square = 9, then square = 15 - 9 = 6.
Inverse operations are opposites that undo each other: addition undoes subtraction, and multiplication undoes division.
Always check your answer by plugging it back in: does 7 + 5 = 12? Yes â€” balanced!

scaffold.title: Finding Missing Numbers â€” Worked Examples

examples.solution:
Think of a balance: the left side must equal 12.
â˜ + 5 = 12
To find â˜, use the inverse of adding 5 â€” subtract 5 from both sides.
â˜ = 12 - 5 = 7
Check: 7 + 5 = 12. Both sides are balanced!

The left side must equal 13.
20 - â˜ = 13
Think: '20 minus what number gives 13?'
Use the inverse: â˜ = 20 - 13 = 7.
Check: 20 - 7 = 13. Balanced!

examples.problem: Solve using a letter: n + 8 = 15. What is n?
examples.solution:
The letter n stands for the unknown number, just like a box.
n + 8 = 15
To get n alone, use the inverse of adding 8 â€” subtract 8.
n = 15 - 8 = 7
Check: 7 + 8 = 15. The equation balances, so n = 7.

problems.question:
Find the missing number: â˜ + 9 = 16
Then check your answer by plugging it back in.
hints: To find â˜, use the inverse of adding 9. What is 16 - 9?
After you find â˜, check: does your answer + 9 equal 16?
problems.answer: â˜ = 16 - 9 = 7. Check: 7 + 9 = 16. Balanced!

problems.question: Solve: 25 - n = 18. What is n?
hints: Think: 25 minus what number gives 18?
Use the inverse: n = 25 - 18.
problems.answer: n = 25 - 18 = 7. Check: 25 - 7 = 18. Balanced!

problems.question:
Is this equation true or false? Explain using the balance idea.
6 + 4 = 5 + 5
hints: Calculate the value of the left side: 6 + 4 = ?
Calculate the value of the right side: 5 + 5 = ?
If both sides have the same value, the equation is true (balanced).
problems.answer: Left side: 6 + 4 = 10. Right side: 5 + 5 = 10. Both sides equal 10, so the equation is TRUE. The equals sign works like a balance â€” both sides weigh the same.
